reviewText:
One of the best (if not the best) Simulation/strategy games I have ever played and I'm finally glad they added it to steam.
I wouldn't even lie if I said I have at least 500+ hours on this game alone and while I played The Guild 2 a lot I still find The Guild 1 much more enjoyable then its sequal.

Although this game is not for everyone I will still HIGHLY recommend playing this one if you want to try it out or if in fact you do love these types of games.

Be aware though that you are going to put a lot of hours in a single playthrough.

Here are my Pros & Cons with at least 500 hours+ of game time.

Pros:
- Different businesses/maps to start out.
- Random events that can turn in or against your favor.
- Courting, No need to feel down if you think you will lose everything cause your character died, have a child!
- Offices in which you can rise high and become an important person - Set tax rates, building rates, allow dueling, and lots more, each office has it own powers.
- Blackmail/bribe/spy on people and there is a lot more you can do.
- Each profession has its ups and downs which also sets the difficulty, want an easy game? try thieves or priests, want a harder game? try landlord or a tailor.

Cons:
- Graphics, it is an old game
- Bugs, You will encounter bugs im pretty sure of it.

Can't think of many cons at the moment but I will be sure to add some more in the future.
voteText: 37 of 40 people (93%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
First let me say I've never played this when it came out, so this review wont have any nostalgia.

Pros:

One of the best resource management games I've ever played.

Really makes you feel like you're running a single business not a whole country like most of these types of games.

Can speed up gameplay if you wish, so you don't have to wait too long for something to finish.

Very intersting and unique jobs.

Good trading system.

Better than it's sequel in my opinion.

Cons:

Old and graphics are very dated.

Can crash on ocasion.

Has some bugs, and no mods or patches that fix them.

Is very addictive.


Overall I think this is a very good game.

reviewText: A nice Medieval life simulator. It is quite old, so the graphics - especially the people animations - are almost painful to look at, while the buildings are still more or less ok. It is fun, even if on the long run it can get a bit boring; all in all, there is not that much that you can do: evolving your buildings, micro-managing the production of some goods to sell, fighting to rise the social ladder applying for jobs in the Empire. Someone really needs to explain to me why if you play in London, the highest authority is the Emperor - meaning the Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire, of which England has never been a part...\nI bought it together with The Guild II and all its expansions; I am pretty sure those are gonna have more to offer, but for less than 1 euro it was definitely worth my time!

reviewText:
One of the best games I have ever played.
It's a terrible shame what has happened to it. It's more likely to fall apart than your great grandma, and steam hasn't done anything about it.
Most people won't even be able to play it, out of the box, because you'll immediately be grappling with CTD and graphical errors (it crashes on widescreen monitors, unless you force it to play in a window, by editting the .ini file).
Even after that, expect to grapple with the controls and the manual (if you can find it).
But, if you like medieval settings, or mercantile simulations, or marrying wealthy widowers, just to quietly poison their tea, this is the game for you. This game is the store bought apple pie, to Dwarf Fortress' First you must create the universe"."

reviewText:
I really like this game, and don't recommend it because it has a particular taste and is overpriced. If you really want a business sim in the 1400's, then this might be for you. If you are willing to do some odd workarounds and have patience with flaws then it's definitely for you. The core of it, a business sim, is still very good.

The game is buggy and unfriendly and has a lot of things going on that it is hard to keep up the patience with. The UI is very very poorly designed - you can learn to like it, but it will take some time. Early game is somewhat ruined by the blatant cheating from the AI. Late game is somewhat ruined by the lack of working auto-features that makes you have to micromanage a lot of things. Sometimes you need to save and reload to be able do do stuff or progress. I hear that it doesn't work with all windows versions either, so check that before you buy it.

And disregard my hours of play, I've had it before I got it on steam.
voteText: 32 of 55 people (58%) found this review helpful 6 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Oh boy, One of my favorite all time games is finally on steam and im already hooked back into it. Dont let the time count fool you i played the original Guild for easily over 1k+ hours back during high school (minus all the patches...) and now we have a fully patched and somewhat great release of The Guild Gold on steam.

I wont ramble too much but heres the jist of the game: You are a poor boy from a poor family out in the forest that comes to the big city to make yourself into something. Sounds simple right? Nope! you cant make yourself super big and successful on your first character so youll be making a Dynasty in the city you'll be playing in to which there are several cities spread across Europe who have their own politics and events to deal with with one of them being other dynasties.

One of the great things about The Guild is that not only are you trying to run your business and not go broke, you also have to not only contend with other dynasties in the same town but also regional politics, everyone can at some point be eligible for every job in the game except for the Emperor/King itself, so while you are climbing the political and economic ladders your opponents and friends in other dynasties will be doing the same, it helps keep the game competitive as it wont take long for you and others to carve battle lines throughout the town (You and your allied Dynasties vs the others).

The game with the expansion pack which is part of the Gold edition allows for a variety of careers to play with, some are downright impossible to play due to being at the mercy of the marketplace or the one place that you and 5 other dynasties are buying stock from while others are so laughably easy that once you have several of these businesses running you only need to focus on politics or underhanded methods to screw around with other dynasties.

But as this is quite an old game it does have its problems, Gold does work on Windows 7 but for some it requires changing the desktop to 16bit to actually play, the game (as well as its sequels) were notoriously buggy at release and while the current final version of gold to my knowledge is bug free keep an eye out while playing as well as save often.

All in all a very enjoyable and comfy game, definitely worth a buy so you can chill out and build your business as the seasons roll on by.

reviewText: For all of you who have problems playing this game smoothly. Simply go to the games directory. reviewText:
Really pleasantly surprised with this one, and having a good time with it.  Came in with low expectations, and it's been a gem so far.  Interesting enough to play with my 10/13-year-old boys, and captures their interest too.  Has a lot of character and charm to it, and the occasional understated humor keeps it lively.  UI is definitely...  not quite painful, but uncomfortable and quirky.

But the UI aside, it's just delightful with its variety and little surprises.  I love the variety there is between how the game plays with different professions.  I just wish multiplayer worked, but I guess when I get to The Guild 2 I'll do it there.

The more I play it, the more I love it.  Heartily recommended.  You *will* have to be patient at first as you scale the learning curve, but it's very much worth the climb.

sgd. Adulterator Luckspeare

reviewText:
As much as I enjoyed playing this game years ago, I cannot recommend it anymore. The game does not work correctly on Windows 8 & 10. It is very laggy to a point of being barely playable (least enjoyable) and even if you manage to make it run smooth in a small window or low resolution fullscreen in the middle of a display with the rest of the screen blacked out, it keeps crashing approximately every half an hour.

If you're running Windows 7 or older, you'll get quite deep trading/building strategy game with social elements reminiscent those of Crusader Kings 2 on a smaller city-level scale. You start the game as one of several handicraft craftsmen and produce, buy and sell goods and later meddle into politics. The game has it's own life of a sort so while a player is doing 'his thing', the other AI characters in game are doing the same. Getting married, producing children, rising into political functions, gaining noble titles based on their wealth, breaking into people's homes and businesses to steal, blackmailing, attending court charges, influencing judges by money/gifts/black magic, abusing political power to own advantage (like outlawing the use of body oils & sprays if your enemy is a perfumer by profession), setting business competitor buildings on fire and so on. The game is not built around a player awaiting his input.

There's quite a lot going on in the game. Once an old character dies and his child takes over, you lose control of other family tree branches, but they still do exist in the background and get on with their lives in game, so you occasionally encounter other people with the same surname (even their descendants) running other businesses or in politics. It's a quite good indicator the game indeed works on deep levels and is not just a shining gold for the eyes pretending to be complex.

Music is absolutely great and is the best medieval styled music I've ever heard in a computer game. This GOLD edition includes an Expansion Pack, which added lot of magic&fantasy styled theme, items, zombies and professions into the game to some extent destroying the feel of more or less realistic medieval period. Back in the days I never installed it, which is not possible with this Gold version.

Overall I always had a blast with this game and sticked to it over it's successor 'The Guild 2' which was plagued by bugs to a point of not being enjoyable. Since there is 'The Guild 3' in development, the newly established team started fixing standalone 'The Guild 2 Renaissance' (which has never been fixed due to it's publisher JoWood going bankrupt) as sort of advertisement for the upcoming game. If anything, I'd suggest skipping this old game on new Windows OS and try 'The Guild 2 Renaissance' with the latest patches available instead. IF you DO run older Windows OS, this game is worth trying, otherwise I have to regrettably suggest avoiding it, despite it's qualities.

reviewText:
I really want to like this game, but I cannot even play it properly.  During the intial install, if you have a graphics card that can support dual monitors, there is a drop down with your graphics card listed twice.  Out of curiosity I picked the second option.

Now, the game movies will play on my primary monitor as they should.  But the game itself plays on my secondary monitor.  I have never found that drop down again, even after uninstalling and reinstalling.  So I cannot recommend this game if it won't even let me change something like which monitor it plays on (AFTER FIRST GIVING ME THAT OPTION AT SETUP!)

If someone can tell me how to fix this issue, I will change my recommendation.

reviewText: It will take at least a full game or two (or three) before you have any idea what you are doing, but even before you learn the ropes, The Guild gold can be strangely addictive but yet has so many rough edges that you might not want to play it at all. The biggest gripe I have with this game, that you can't alt-tab or run in windows mode. Before the gold edition, you could fix this problem with a registry edit. However, with the gold edition, the developers took that option away. Because of that, I refuse to recommend this game. It's not a bad game, it's the kind of game that either enthralls you for days on end or drives you up the wall to gnaw at the curtain rods. Regardless, the developers are ♥♥♥♥♥♥ for disabling alt-tab and not including a windows mode. My advice, get this game in a humblebundle and make sure all the proceeds goes to charity. The developers deserve nothing!

reviewText:
═══════════════════════════════════
Overview:The Guild Gold Edition is a very flawed business simulator with a decent storyline. It is set within the 1400s, with you being a poor boy in search of becoming rich and creating a successful dynasty. The game itself feels very unfinished with bugs left, right and center and animations being off with the sound/voice acting. The first couple of minutes into this game, really made me want to play it. It had a brilliant storyline, the cutscenes were captivating and seemed like an interesting concept, though getting into the main menu and finding out that ALT+TAB and the Steam Overlay don't work made me instantly feel it was user unfriendly. The tutorial also was very lacking and bugged quite a bit.

═══════════════════════════════════
Positives:☆Good storyline.
☆Good voice acting.
☆Good music.
☆Sound effects are good.

Negatives:☆Animations off point with sound/voice acting.
☆Mouse felt laggy and quite buggy.
☆Tutorial was glitched, unable to click the dynasty symbol.
☆Steam Overlay was disabled.

═══════════════════════════════════
Summary:Overall, this game felt like an unfinished and buggy mess with a decent concept. This, to me, would be for nostalgia reasons or unless you are able to play through the bugs and glitches that the game has to offer. This was a great concept, which will be interesting in the upcoming Guild 3, though for now a buggy mess.
